scopecontent.p: These four volumes contain the notes of Howard H. Hopkins while a student at an unidentified institution during the early 1830s. The subjects covered by these notebooks are single bookkeeping, double bookkeeping, geometry and architecture. All contain ornate lettering of the subject headings as well as some carefully drawn and painted geometric and architectural figures. Included in the single bookkeeping notebook is a commencement address describing Hopkins' reflections of his school experiences. Although Hopkins never notes the name of this institution, it may have been a boarding school type based on his description of the place as an "interesting village" where he received much attention and affection for two years.
